Title: On-Field Exertional Heat Stroke - Emergency Management

Root.Prompt: A collegiate lineman collapses after practice. Rectal temp is 40.5 C, confused and combative. What is your first action?

Info.narration: Late-August practice, high heat and humidity. You have assistants, ice, oxygen, IV supplies, and EMS phone access.

Choices.Label: A
Choices.Text: Start immediate cold-water immersion, remove equipment, assign one person to call EMS and one to monitor vitals.
Choices.Feedback: Correct. Cool first, transport second for exertional heat stroke.

Next.Prompt: After 6 minutes of immersion: temp 39.0 C, mental status improving. EMS is still 12 minutes away. What next?

Choices.Label: A
Choices.Text: Continue immersion until under 39.0 C, provide oxygen, prepare IV access, and continue monitoring.
Choices.Feedback: Correct. Continue active cooling and supportive care.

Next.Prompt: Temp reaches 38.5 C, vitals stabilize, and EMS transport is completed with structured handoff.

Choices.Label: B
Choices.Text: Stop immersion early and switch to passive cooling only.
Choices.Feedback: Suboptimal. Stopping early can lead to rebound hyperthermia.

Next.Prompt: Patient initially looks better but later deteriorates from inadequate cooling.

Choices.Label: B
Choices.Text: Use shade, fans, and ice packs only while waiting for EMS.
Choices.Feedback: Too slow for severe heat stroke with neurologic symptoms.

Next.Prompt: Temperature remains dangerously high and neurologic status worsens before definitive care.

Choices.Label: C
Choices.Text: Give oral fluids and observe without aggressive cooling.

Next.Prompt: Patient deteriorates rapidly from untreated exertional heat stroke.
